The fact that she couldn't get a bail bond is why she was kept in jail for three days instead of being released. If she had been able to post bail on the first day, she would've been released at that time. Because she couldn't provide bail, she was facing much longer than three days, in fact weeks or possibly even months in jail waiting for a court date. They also charged her with a felony based on the officer's claim that she assaulted him during the arrest; as a result, she was facing the possibility of a prison sentence. It appears likely that officer Encinia was operating a ticket trap on that lightly traveled road, where we can see in the video that there was almost no traffic at that time. He stopped her for a minor violation because he can do that, not because of any danger that her driving might have caused for other drivers.

Anyhow, If I were as young as you, I would grow facial hair.

Denial is the refusal to accept reality or fact, acting as if a painful event, thought or feeling did not exist. It is considered one of the most primitive of the defense mechanisms because it is characteristic of early childhood development. Many people use denial in their everyday lives to avoid dealing with painful feelings or areas of their life they don’t wish to admit.

Susan, the IPCC predictions of temperature have been consistently high. The lower than "expected" rise in temperature is commonly known as the "pause" or the "hiatus."

Tenney feel free to educate me as to where I am wrong:

Here is the Hansen prediction (forecast) versus reality:

http://c3headlines.typepad.com/.a/6a010536b58035970c01b7c748813e970b-pi

The planet has been warming since the Little Ice Age ended, it warmed faster and sea levels rose faster before industrialization than since, and more in the early part of the 20th century than the more recent times, all this despite continuously added carbon and all accumulated carbon.

http://c3headlines.typepad.com/.a/6a010536b58035970c01b7c738ed49970b-pi

Hansen own data set (the area he retired from) NASA GISS shows a pause, and, 17 years absent statistically significant warming. Other data sets show the same but for as long as 23 years.

The lower troposphere has not warmed in 18 years and 6 months.

The earth has been cooling since 2002 according to hadCRUT4 data.

The only thing that seems ripe to perhaps cause these things to alter, is the presently forming el nino which may indeed cause more apparent warming just as happened in 1998, after which the pause began and cooling ensued, thereafter.

You will find that all of this, both the warming periods and the not warming periods and the cooling periods follow a trend line from before 1850 with changes in ocean and solar cycles imposed upon that trend by natural variation, and the trend itself essentially unchanged.

A look at the GISS data set shows about 0.5C of warming added that was never measured but adjusted into the set.

David -

SLR of 6 mm/year equates to roughly two feet per century. Two feet per century is not twenty feet per century. The latter is Hansen’s unsupported conjecture.

When you site future mega cities (like New York) on the what is, at the time of their Little Ice Age settlement, land that is slightly above sea level, even a rise of sea level of one or two feet over the next 100 years will have consequences that require adaptation.

We can’t change what the oceans will do over the next 100 years, David, even if a thousand nuclear power plants were to be put online within the next decade.

A hundred years from now human civilization will almost certainly be powered by non-carbonaceous fuels, should humanity survive the many very real threats to its existence in the interim.

Human carbon emissions fit a certain political and environmental narrative, however, they are otherwise the most inconsequential of existential threats.

Susan,

Your last paragraph doesn't seem to fit into our discussion. Here's why all this matters. Climate science is the investigation phase of an action. That action is mitigation and adaptation. We know mitigation is simply to stop emitting lots and lots of GHG. Adaptation is going to involve infrastructure builds and is going to be expensive as hell. Climate science is really just the establishment of physical conditions, both baseline and projected, for construction and operations of public and private endeavors. It has to be pretty darn right. Climate science isn't the end all. It's the first deliverable.

The Army Corps of Engineers will be the ones having to modify, retrofit and rebuild coastal facilities for military and commerce. It will be essential for physical conditions to be well agreed upon before spending billions on a build. Sea level and coastal impact scenarios should get peer reviewed both within climate investigation agencies and without.

Here's how USACE is tasked with adaptation:
http://www.corpsclimate.us/index.cfm

and here's how GAO is concerned about USACE's backlog and whether it's funded or not:

http://www.climatecentral.org/news/gao-climate-risks-army-corps-projects...

"The gold standard of peer review," has been all OVER this rough draft being prepared for formal publication from before its first posting, it would seem.

Can you say as much for, say, WUWT, or FOX, or even Judith Curry's stuff?

By the way, I certainly hope you lot READ Revkin's article for a change. You'd learn rather a great deal about critiquing the science and the writing in scientific and literate terms, as opposed to...well, you know. the stuff that you do.

And "LIA," designates a climatological event that took place mostly in Northern Europe, not a socio-historical period, which again suggests not only your ethnocentrism, but your profound lack of the basics.
Given that Sagan's work on planetary atmospheres, the greenhouse effect, and "nuclear winter," ended up being intertwined, it's hilarious that you'd make such claims.
